sites.name: Palermo Cathedral (Cattedrale di Palermo)
sites.description: A unique architectural complex characterized by the presence of different styles, due to a long history of additions, alterations and restorations, the last of which occurred in the 18th century. Built on the site of a Muslim mosque, it showcases Norman, Gothic, Baroque, and Neoclassical elements. Houses royal tombs and a treasury.
sites.seasonal_notes: Impressive year-round. Rooftop access offers great views, best on clear days. Can be crowded during peak season (summer).
sites.booking_tips: Free entry to the main church area. Tickets required for treasury, crypts, tombs, and rooftop access. Combo tickets available. Book rooftop tickets online in advance, especially in summer. Modest dress required.

sites.name: Norman Palace (Palazzo dei Normanni) & Palatine Chapel (Cappella Palatina)
sites.description: The oldest royal residence in Europe, the seat of the Kings of Sicily during the Norman domination and served afterwards as the main seat of power for the subsequent rulers of Sicily. Features the stunning Palatine Chapel, a masterpiece of Arab-Norman-Byzantine style with breathtaking golden mosaics.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. The mosaics in the chapel are best viewed with good light. Can get very crowded; visiting early or during the off-season is recommended.
sites.booking_tips: Booking tickets online in advance is highly recommended to avoid long queues. Ticket includes access to the Royal Apartments (subject to parliamentary sessions), Palatine Chapel, and Royal Gardens. Allow ample time.

sites.name: Teatro Massimo
sites.description: Italy's largest opera house and the third largest in Europe. Renowned for its perfect acoustics and neoclassical architecture. Famous as a filming location for 'The Godfather Part III'. Offers guided tours and hosts opera, ballet, and concert performances.
sites.seasonal_notes: Performance season typically runs from fall to spring. Tours available year-round. Check the schedule for performances.
sites.booking_tips: Book performance tickets well in advance. Guided tours are available daily in multiple languages; booking tours online is recommended. Check tour times.

sites.name: Quattro Canti
sites.description: An octagonal Baroque square marking the intersection of Palermo's two main streets, Via Maqueda and Corso Vittorio Emanuele. Each of the four corners features ornate facades with fountains, statues representing the four seasons, Spanish kings, and patron saints of Palermo.
sites.seasonal_notes: A central hub year-round. Beautifully lit in the evening. Can be very busy with traffic and pedestrians.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. It's a public intersection. Best viewed by walking around. Be mindful of traffic.

sites.name: Fontana Pretoria (Fountain of Shame)
sites.description: A monumental Renaissance fountain located in Piazza Pretoria, adjacent to Quattro Canti. Originally built in Florence, it was moved to Palermo in the 16th century. Features numerous nude statues of mythological figures and animals, which earned it the nickname 'Fountain of Shame'.
sites.seasonal_notes: Visible year-round. Best viewed in daylight to appreciate the details. The surrounding piazza is lively.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. It's a public monument. Often fenced off for protection, but easily visible. Great photo opportunities.

sites.name: Mercato di Ballarò
sites.description: Palermo's largest, oldest, and most famous street market. A vibrant, chaotic, and sensory experience reminiscent of an Arab souk. Offers fresh produce, fish, meat, cheese, street food (like 'pane ca meusa'), clothing, and household goods. Known for the vendors' loud calls ('abbanniate').
sites.seasonal_notes: Most active in the mornings, especially on weekdays and Saturdays. Quieter on Sundays and afternoons. Offers seasonal produce.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Best explored on foot. Be prepared for crowds and noise. Try the street food! Bargaining is common. Be aware of your surroundings.

sites.name: Capuchin Catacombs (Catacombe dei Cappuccini)
sites.description: A macabre but fascinating historical cemetery containing thousands of mummified bodies dating from the 17th to the early 20th century. Bodies are dressed and arranged in corridors according to status and profession. Offers a unique, albeit somber, glimpse into past funerary practices.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round, though hours might vary slightly. Consistent cool temperature inside.
sites.booking_tips: Tickets purchased at the entrance. Not recommended for young children or the easily disturbed. Photography is strictly forbidden. Modest dress advised.

sites.name: Church of Martorana (Santa Maria dell'Ammiraglio)
sites.description: An exquisite example of Norman architecture combined with Byzantine mosaics, located in Piazza Bellini. Famous for its stunning 12th-century golden mosaics depicting Christ Pantocrator and scenes from the Bible. Adjacent to the Church of San Cataldo.
sites.seasonal_notes: Mosaics are impressive year-round. Can be busy, especially when tour groups arrive.
sites.booking_tips: Small entrance fee. Modest dress required (shoulders and knees covered). Check opening hours as they can vary and it closes during services. Often visited together with San Cataldo.

sites.name: Monte Pellegrino & Sanctuary of Santa Rosalia
sites.description: A large limestone mountain overlooking Palermo Bay, described by Goethe as 'the most beautiful promontory in the world'. Home to the Sanctuary of Santa Rosalia, Palermo's patron saint, built within a cave. Offers panoramic views of the city and sea.
sites.seasonal_notes: Best visited on clear days for views. Can be windy. Popular pilgrimage site, especially around Santa Rosalia's feast day in July/September. Cooler than the city in summer.
sites.booking_tips: Accessible by car or public bus (line 812 from Piazza Sturzo). The sanctuary visit is free (donations welcome). Wear comfortable shoes if exploring. Allow time for travel up/down.

sites.name: Giardino Garibaldi
sites.description: An elegant public garden in Piazza Marina, known for its spectacular giant Ficus macrophylla trees with aerial roots. Provides a shady oasis in the Kalsa district. Hosts a popular antiques and flea market on Sundays.
sites.seasonal_notes: Pleasant year-round. Offers shade in summer. Sunday market adds significant activity.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Great place for a relaxing break. Check market days if interested in antiques.

sites.name: Salinas Archaeological Museum (Museo Archeologico Regionale Antonio Salinas)
sites.description: One of Italy's richest archaeological museums, housed in a former monastery. Features an extensive collection of Punic and Ancient Greek art, artifacts from Sicilian history including findings from Selinunte, Mozia, and Himera, and Roman items.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. A good indoor activity for hot or rainy days. Check for temporary exhibitions.
sites.booking_tips: Tickets available at the entrance or online. Allow sufficient time to explore the extensive collection. Audio guides may be available.

neighborhoods.name: Centro Storico (Kalsa, Castellammare, Albergheria, Monte di Pietà)
neighborhoods.character: The ancient heart of Palermo, a dense network of narrow streets, bustling markets, baroque churches, noble palaces, and vibrant piazzas reflecting millennia of history and diverse cultural influences (Arab, Norman, Spanish).

location.description: Comprises the four historic quarters (mandamenti) radiating from Quattro Canti: Kalsa, Albergheria, Castellammare/Loggia, and Monte di Pietà/Capo.

history.overview: Palermo's historic core, shaped by Phoenicians, Romans, Arabs, Normans, Swabians, Spanish, and Bourbons. Each conqueror left their mark on the architecture and urban layout.
history.significance: Contains one of Europe's largest historic centers, showcasing a unique blend of architectural styles and hosting numerous UNESCO World Heritage sites.
notable_events: Heavy bombing during WWII and subsequent decay/revitalization

practical_info.safety: Generally safe during the day, especially main streets and tourist areas. Some alleys can feel deserted or sketchy at night. Be aware of surroundings, especially in crowded markets (pickpockets). Ballarò and Vucciria require more caution after dark.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Daytime for sightseeing and markets, evenings (especially weekends) for lively atmosphere in areas like Vucciria and around Teatro Massimo.
practical_info.walkability: Extremely walkable, though navigating the maze-like streets can be challenging. Cobblestones common.

attractions.name: Norman Palace & Palatine Chapel
attractions.description: Oldest royal residence in Europe with stunning Byzantine mosaics in the chapel.
attractions.appeal: Must-see for its historical significance and breathtaking art.

attractions.name: Palermo Cathedral
attractions.description: Unique blend of architectural styles reflecting Palermo's history.

attractions.name: Ballarò Market
attractions.description: Largest and most chaotic street market, known for food and lively atmosphere.
attractions.appeal: Authentic sensory experience and great street food.

dining.name: Antica Focacceria San Francesco
dining.known_for: Historic eatery famous for 'pani ca meusa' and 'panelle'.

dining.name: Ke Palle (Arancine d'Autore)
dining.known_for: Wide variety of creative and traditional arancini.

dining.name: Osteria dei Vespri
dining.known_for: Refined Sicilian cuisine in an elegant setting near Piazza Pretoria.

activities.name: Street Food Tour
activities.description: Guided exploration of markets like Ballarò and Capo, tasting local specialties.

activities.name: Exploring the Markets (Ballarò, Vucciria, Capo)
activities.description: Wander through the vibrant, historic street markets absorbing the sights, sounds, and smells.

stay_here_if: You want to be immersed in history and close to major sights.
You love vibrant, chaotic atmospheres and street markets.
You want easy access to a wide variety of dining and street food.
avoid_if: You are highly sensitive to noise and crowds.
You prioritize modern amenities and easy parking.
You feel uncomfortable in slightly gritty urban environments after dark.
insider_tips: Markets are best visited in the morning for peak activity and freshness.
Get lost in the side streets (during the day) to discover hidden churches and squares.
Vucciria market is mostly dormant during the day but transforms into an outdoor nightlife hub on weekend evenings.
Wear comfortable shoes for the uneven cobblestone streets.

neighborhoods.name: Politeama/Libertà
neighborhoods.character: Palermo's elegant and modern commercial heart, characterized by wide avenues, designer shops, Art Nouveau architecture, theaters, and upscale residences.

location.description: Northwest of the Centro Storico, centered around Piazza Politeama and extending along Via Libertà.

history.overview: Developed primarily in the late 19th and early 20th centuries during Palermo's Belle Époque, becoming the center for the city's bourgeoisie and modern commercial life.
history.significance: Represents Palermo's modern face, contrasting with the ancient Centro Storico. Hub for shopping, business, and cultural institutions like theaters.
notable_events: Development of Via Libertà as a prestigious avenue
Flourishing of Art Nouveau (Stile Liberty) architecture

practical_info.safety: Generally considered very safe, well-lit, and policed day and night.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Daytime for shopping, evening for passeggiata (stroll), theater, and dining.
practical_info.walkability: Highly walkable with wide, flat sidewalks along main avenues.

best_for: Travelers seeking modern comforts and amenities

attractions.name: Teatro Politeama Garibaldi
attractions.description: Iconic theater with a distinctive neoclassical entrance arch, hosting concerts and events.

attractions.name: Via Libertà
attractions.description: Palermo's main upscale shopping street, lined with designer boutiques and cafes.
attractions.appeal: Window shopping, people-watching, experiencing modern Palermo.

attractions.name: Giardino Inglese
attractions.description: Elegant 19th-century public garden with fountains, exotic plants, and sculptures.
attractions.appeal: Peaceful retreat for a stroll or relaxation.

dining.name: Gagini Social Restaurant
dining.known_for: Creative cuisine in a chic, historic setting (former sculptor's studio).

dining.name: Pasticceria Cappello
dining.known_for: Famous for traditional Sicilian pastries, especially 'Setteveli' cake.

dining.name: Cioccolateria Lorenzo
dining.known_for: High-quality chocolates, coffee, and sophisticated snacks.

activities.name: Shopping on Via Libertà
activities.description: Browse high-end fashion boutiques and international brands.

activities.name: Evening Passeggiata
activities.description: Join locals for the traditional evening stroll along Via Libertà and surrounding streets.

stay_here_if: You prioritize shopping and modern conveniences.
You prefer a more elegant, orderly, and safer-feeling environment.
You need easy access to the airport bus.
You plan to attend performances at Teatro Politeama or Teatro Massimo.
avoid_if: You are looking for the historic, chaotic charm of Old Town Palermo.
You are on a tight budget (accommodation and dining tend to be pricier).
You want to be steps away from the main historical monuments.
insider_tips: Via Libertà is partially pedestrianized on some weekends, making it great for strolling.
Explore the side streets off Via Libertà for interesting boutiques and cafes.
The area around Teatro Politeama is a major hub for city buses.

neighborhoods.name: Mondello
neighborhoods.character: Palermo's seaside resort town, famous for its long sandy beach, clear turquoise waters, Art Nouveau pier ('Charleston'), and lively summer atmosphere. Primarily a residential area for wealthier Palermitans outside the summer season.

location.description: Located about 11 km north of Palermo city center, nestled between Monte Pellegrino and Monte Gallo.

history.overview: Originally a marshy area, Mondello was drained and developed as a prestigious seaside resort in the early 20th century, characterized by numerous Art Nouveau villas.
history.significance: Serves as Palermo's primary beach destination and a symbol of the city's Belle Époque seaside leisure.
notable_events: Construction of Art Nouveau villas and Stabilimento Balneare (early 20th C)
Became popular beach destination for Palermitans

transit: Bus line 806 connects directly to Politeama area (approx. 30-40 min)
Limited parking, especially in summer (can be expensive)
practical_info.safety: Generally very safe, especially in the main beach and piazza areas. Standard precautions apply.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Late Spring (May-June) and Early Fall (September-October) for pleasant weather and fewer crowds. Summer (July-August) is peak season, very crowded and lively. Winter is very quiet.
practical_info.walkability: Highly walkable along the beachfront promenade and within the main town area.

best_for: Travelers wanting a break from the city bustle

attractions.name: Mondello Beach
attractions.description: Long crescent of fine white sand with shallow, clear turquoise water.
attractions.appeal: Ideal for swimming, sunbathing, and relaxing.

attractions.name: Antico Stabilimento Balneare (Charleston)
attractions.description: Iconic Art Nouveau structure on a pier extending into the sea, housing a restaurant and event space.
attractions.appeal: Architectural gem and symbol of Mondello.

attractions.name: Capo Gallo Nature Reserve
attractions.description: Coastal reserve adjacent to Mondello offering hiking trails and rocky coastline.
attractions.appeal: Nature walks and coastal views away from the main beach.

dining.name: Bye Bye Blues
dining.known_for: Fine dining experience with creative seafood dishes.

dining.name: Trattoria da Calogero
dining.known_for: Fresh fish and classic Sicilian seafood preparations.

dining.name: Touring Cafè Beach
dining.known_for: Casual spot on the beach for gelato, coffee, snacks, and aperitivo.

activities.name: Beach Day
activities.description: Spend the day swimming, sunbathing, and renting paddle boats or kayaks.

activities.name: Walk the Lungomare
activities.description: Stroll along the beachfront promenade, enjoying the views and atmosphere.

stay_here_if: Your main goal is a beach vacation.
You want a more relaxed, resort-like atmosphere.
You are visiting in summer and want easy beach access.
You don't mind commuting to the city center for sightseeing.
avoid_if: You want to be close to Palermo's historical sites and museums.
You are visiting in winter (many places close or have reduced hours).
You dislike very crowded beaches (in peak summer).
You rely heavily on public transport late at night.
insider_tips: The beach is divided into free sections (spiaggia libera) and private lidos where you pay for umbrellas/chairs.
Bus 806 can get extremely crowded in summer; consider a taxi for more comfort.
Visit during the week or shoulder season (May/June, Sept/Oct) for a more relaxed experience.
The water stays warm enough for swimming well into October.

fine_dining.name: Gagini Social Restaurant
fine_dining.atmosphere: Stylish, contemporary, housed in a former sculptor's studio
fine_dining.booking_tips: Book well in advance, especially for weekends. Ideal for special occasions.
fine_dining.local_tips: Known for innovative cuisine and presentation in a unique historical setting.

fine_dining.name: Osteria dei Vespri
fine_dining.atmosphere: Elegant and intimate setting in Piazza Croce dei Vespri
fine_dining.booking_tips: Reservations highly recommended. Good wine list.
fine_dining.local_tips: Offers a sophisticated take on Sicilian classics in a beautiful square.

fine_dining.name: Bye Bye Blues (Mondello)
fine_dining.atmosphere: Elegant, refined, located near the sea in Mondello
fine_dining.booking_tips: Book well in advance. Located outside the city center in Mondello.
fine_dining.local_tips: Considered one of Sicily's top fine dining experiences, focusing on seafood.

casual_dining.name: Trattoria Corona
casual_dining.booking_tips: Popular, booking advised, especially for dinner.
casual_dining.local_tips: Focuses on fresh, simply prepared seafood.

casual_dining.name: Osteria Alivàru
casual_dining.booking_tips: Small place, booking essential. Ask for daily specials.
casual_dining.local_tips: Known for soulful, home-style cooking using seasonal ingredients.

casual_dining.name: Ferro di Cavallo
casual_dining.atmosphere: Lively, chaotic, traditional trattoria with shared tables
casual_dining.booking_tips: Be prepared for a bustling, noisy atmosphere. Popular with locals.
casual_dining.local_tips: A Palermo institution known for its classic dishes and vibrant chaos.

casual_dining.name: Trattoria Piccolo Napoli
signature_dishes: Spaghetti con i Ricci (Sea Urchin Pasta - seasonal)
casual_dining.booking_tips: Essential to book, especially weekends. Ask about the catch of the day.
casual_dining.local_tips: Authentic seafood experience, slightly off the main tourist path.

casual_dining.name: FUD Bottega Sicula
casual_dining.reservation_needed: Often busy, might need to wait
casual_dining.booking_tips: Good selection of Sicilian craft beers and wines.
casual_dining.local_tips: Offers a modern, gourmet take on Sicilian ingredients, including unusual meats.

street_food.name: Antica Focacceria San Francesco
street_food.local_tips: Historic institution for Palermo street food, founded in 1834.

street_food.name: Nni Franco U Vastiddaru
street_food.location: Via Vittorio Emanuele / Piazza Marina area
street_food.local_tips: Considered one of the best places for Pani ca Meusa (spleen sandwich).

street_food.name: Ke Palle Arancine d'Autore
street_food.local_tips: Modern spot specializing in arancine with both classic and inventive fillings.

street_food.name: Ballarò Market Stalls
street_food.local_tips: Explore the market for a variety of authentic, gritty street food experiences.

street_food.name: Capo Market Stalls
street_food.local_tips: Another great market for sampling various street foods in a lively atmosphere.

coffee_shops.name: Casa Stagnitta
coffee_shops.atmosphere: Modern, popular cafe near Quattro Canti
coffee_shops.local_tips: Excellent quality coffee and a good spot for breakfast or a break.

coffee_shops.name: Pasticceria Cappello
coffee_shops.atmosphere: Historic, elegant pastry shop and café
coffee_shops.food_options: Extensive range of pastries, cakes, gelato
coffee_shops.local_tips: Famous for the rich, seven-layer chocolate Setteveli cake. Located near Monreale bus stop.

coffee_shops.name: Pasticceria Costa
coffee_shops.local_tips: Long-standing reputation for high-quality traditional Sicilian pastries.

coffee_shops.name: Bar Vabres
coffee_shops.local_tips: Good spot for a typical Italian breakfast like locals.

coffee_shops.name: I Segreti del Chiostro (Convento di Santa Caterina)
coffee_shops.atmosphere: Unique setting within a historic convent
coffee_shops.food_options: Only traditional Sicilian sweets based on convent recipes
coffee_shops.local_tips: Incredible traditional sweets made by lay women using ancient recipes. A must-visit.

bars.name: Bottega Monteleone
bars.atmosphere: Cozy, traditional enoteca (wine shop) with seating
bars.local_tips: Great place to sample local wines by the glass or bottle with knowledgeable staff.

bars.name: CiCala
bars.atmosphere: Stylish, modern bar near the Cala (marina)
bars.local_tips: Exceptional selection of Marsala wines and a curated list of other Sicilian/international wines.

bars.name: Ballarak
bars.local_tips: Great spot for craft beer lovers with a good selection on tap.

bars.name: Bar Botanico
bars.local_tips: Known for its creative cocktails and lively, sometimes party-like atmosphere.

bars.name: Vucciria Market (Evening)
bars.atmosphere: Chaotic, loud, outdoor street party (especially weekends)
bars.local_tips: Not a single bar, but the whole square turns into an open-air drinking area. Very local, very intense.

food_tours.name: Palermo Street Food Walking Tour (e.g., Streaty)
highlights: Tasting Panelle, Arancine, Pani ca Meusa, Sfincione
Learning about food history and culture
food_tours.booking_tips: Book in advance, wear comfortable shoes, come hungry!

food_tours.name: Market Tour & Tasting
food_tours.focus: Exploring Ballarò or Capo Market in depth
highlights: Tasting fresh produce, cheese, olives, street food
food_tours.booking_tips: Best done in the morning when markets are most active.

cooking_classes.name: Sicilian Cooking Class
includes: Market visit (often), ingredients, hands-on instruction, lunch/dinner with wine
cooking_classes.booking_tips: Search for classes that include a market visit for a fuller experience. Book ahead.

cooking_classes.name: Palermo Home Cooking Experience
includes: Instruction in a local's home, ingredients, shared meal
cooking_classes.booking_tips: Offers a more personal and authentic cultural immersion. Availability may be limited.

markets.name: Ballarò Market
highlights: Vast array of produce, fish, meat
markets.hours: Morning to early afternoon (food stalls may stay open longer)
markets.local_tips: Oldest, largest, and most chaotic market. Be aware of surroundings.

markets.name: Mercato del Capo
markets.location: Monte di Pietà district (Enter via Porta Carini)
markets.local_tips: Still very lively but slightly less overwhelming than Ballarò.

markets.name: Vucciria Market
highlights: Historically significant market (less daytime food now)
Street food vendors appear in evening
markets.hours: Limited daytime food stalls; Evening/Night for drinks/food
markets.local_tips: Visit during the day for history, visit at night (weekends) for the street party vibe.

summer: Pasta con le Sarde (peak season for wild fennel)

activities.name: Settimana Santa (Holy Week Processions)
activities.description: Experience deeply traditional and often dramatic religious processions winding through the historic streets of Palermo and nearby towns during the week leading up to Easter.
activities.seasonal_notes: A major cultural and religious event in Sicily. Dates vary based on Easter. Processions can be solemn and crowded.
activities.booking_tips: Check local schedules for specific procession routes and times. Be respectful of the religious nature.

activities.name: Visit to Monreale Cathedral & Cloisters
activities.description: Take a day trip to nearby Monreale to see the stunning Norman cathedral and cloisters, particularly beautiful in the spring light.
activities.seasonal_notes: Pleasant weather for the trip and exploring the town. Gardens are blooming.
activities.booking_tips: Easily accessible by bus from Palermo. Purchase cathedral/cloister tickets on site or potentially online.

activities.name: Stroll through Villa Giulia & Botanical Gardens
activities.description: Enjoy Palermo's historic public garden and adjacent botanical gardens as flowers come into bloom.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring brings lush greenery and blooming flowers, making it the ideal time to visit.
activities.booking_tips: Check opening hours for the Botanical Gardens. Villa Giulia is a public park.

activities.name: Explore Outdoor Markets (Ballarò, Capo)
activities.description: Wander through Palermo's vibrant outdoor markets, enjoying the seasonal spring produce like artichokes and fava beans.
activities.seasonal_notes: Markets are bustling with fresh spring vegetables and a lively atmosphere.
activities.booking_tips: Go early for the best selection and atmosphere. Be prepared for crowds.

activities.name: May Day (Primo Maggio) Activities
activities.description: Experience local traditions for Labor Day (May 1st), which often involves picnics, outings to the countryside, or special events in the city.
activities.seasonal_notes: May 1st is a public holiday. Many shops may be closed, but parks and outdoor spaces are popular.
activities.booking_tips: Check for specific local events announced closer to the date.

activities.name: Festino di Santa Rosalia
activities.description: Palermo's most important festival celebrating its patron saint, Santa Rosalia. Features a grand procession with a triumphal chariot, fireworks, music, and street food.
activities.seasonal_notes: Peak celebration occurs July 10-15, culminating on the night of the 14th. Very crowded and lively.
activities.booking_tips: Find a viewing spot early, especially along the procession route (Cassaro/Foro Italico). Be prepared for huge crowds.

activities.name: Mondello Beach Days
activities.description: Spend time at Palermo's famous sandy beach, swimming, sunbathing, and enjoying the seaside atmosphere.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer is peak season for Mondello. Expect large crowds, especially on weekends. Water is warm.
activities.booking_tips: Take bus 806 from Politeama. Go early to secure a spot, especially on weekends. Renting chairs/umbrella at a lido offers convenience.

activities.name: World Festival on the Beach (Mondello)
activities.description: An international event held in Mondello featuring watersports competitions (windsurf, kitesurf), beach volleyball, music, and food stands.
activities.seasonal_notes: Typically held in late May or June, marking the start of the summer beach season. Lively atmosphere.
activities.booking_tips: Check official dates annually. Events centered around Piazza Valdesi and the beach.

activities.name: Outdoor Concerts and Cinema
activities.description: Enjoy open-air concerts, film screenings, and theater performances often held in historic courtyards or parks as part of summer arts festivals ('Palermo Estate').
activities.seasonal_notes: Various locations host events throughout summer. Check local listings ('Palermo Estate' programs).
activities.booking_tips: Some events may require advance ticket purchase. Check schedules online or at tourist info points.

activities.name: Sicilian Jazz Festival
activities.description: Major jazz festival featuring international and Italian artists performing in various venues across Palermo.
activities.seasonal_notes: Usually held over several weeks in July/August. Features big names and local talent.
activities.booking_tips: Check the official festival schedule and book tickets for headline acts well in advance.

activities.name: Evening Passeggiata & Granita
activities.description: Join locals for the traditional evening stroll (passeggiata) along main streets like Via Maqueda or the Foro Italico promenade, followed by a refreshing granita.
activities.seasonal_notes: A quintessential Italian summer evening ritual. Perfect way to cool down and people-watch.
activities.booking_tips: No booking needed. Find a good gelateria/bar for granita (lemon, almond, coffee are classics).

activities.name: Boat Trip along the Coast
activities.description: Take a boat tour from Palermo's ports (Cala, Mondello) to explore nearby coves, swim in clear waters, and see the coastline from the sea.
activities.seasonal_notes: Ideal summer activity to escape the city heat and enjoy the sea.
activities.booking_tips: Various tour operators offer trips. Book in advance, especially in July/August. Options range from short trips to full-day excursions.

activities.name: Le Vie dei Tesori (Treasures' Ways)
activities.description: A major cultural event where hundreds of normally inaccessible historical sites, palaces, churches, and gardens across Palermo open their doors to the public.
activities.seasonal_notes: Typically held over several weekends in September/October. Incredible opportunity for cultural discovery.
activities.booking_tips: Check the official program released annually. Purchase a pass for multiple entries. Some sites require booking specific time slots.

activities.name: Theater and Opera Season Opening
activities.description: Attend the opening performances of the new season at Palermo's prestigious theaters like Teatro Massimo and Teatro Politeama.
activities.seasonal_notes: The main cultural seasons typically kick off in the autumn months.
activities.booking_tips: Book tickets well in advance for popular opera or theater productions. Check theater websites for schedules.

activities.name: Hiking in Nearby Nature Reserves (Zingaro, Madonie)
activities.description: Take advantage of the cooler autumn weather for hiking in beautiful nature reserves accessible as day trips from Palermo.
activities.seasonal_notes: Autumn offers ideal temperatures for hiking, less crowded trails than summer. Scenery can be beautiful with autumn colors.
activities.booking_tips: Requires own transport or organized tour. Check reserve opening times and trail conditions.

activities.name: Visit Indoor Museums & Galleries
activities.description: Explore Palermo's rich museum collections, such as the Salinas Archaeological Museum or the Galleria d'Arte Moderna, during pleasant autumn days.
activities.seasonal_notes: Good activity for potentially rainier autumn days. Less crowded than summer.
activities.booking_tips: Check opening hours. Consider combined museum passes if available.

activities.name: Wine Tasting in Western Sicily
activities.description: Explore the wine regions west of Palermo (e.g., around Marsala, Alcamo) during or just after the harvest season.
activities.seasonal_notes: Autumn is the wine harvest season ('vendemmia'), offering a chance to see vineyards in action or taste new wines.
activities.booking_tips: Requires own transport or organized wine tour. Book winery visits and tastings in advance.

activities.name: Christmas Markets & Decorations
activities.description: Explore festive Christmas markets set up in various squares (e.g., Piazza Castelnuovo/Politeama) and enjoy the holiday lights and decorations along main streets.
activities.seasonal_notes: Markets typically run from early December through Epiphany (Jan 6). Atmosphere is festive, especially in the evenings.
activities.booking_tips: No booking needed. Good place to find local crafts and sweets.

activities.name: New Year's Eve Celebrations
activities.description: Join public celebrations for New Year's Eve, often featuring a large concert and fireworks display in Piazza Politeama or near Teatro Massimo.
activities.seasonal_notes: Large crowds gather for the main public concert and countdown. Restaurants offer special 'cenone' dinners.
activities.booking_tips: Arrive early for a good spot at the public concert. Book New Year's Eve dinner reservations far in advance.

activities.name: Presepi Viventi (Living Nativities)
activities.description: Visit traditional living nativity scenes ('presepi viventi') often staged in historic settings in Palermo or nearby towns during the Christmas season.
activities.seasonal_notes: A charming Sicilian Christmas tradition. Usually runs from mid-December to early January.
activities.booking_tips: Check local listings for locations and opening times. Some are quite elaborate.

activities.name: Opera and Concert Season
activities.description: Enjoy the main season for opera, ballet, and classical music concerts at Teatro Massimo and other venues.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter is the peak season for indoor performing arts.
activities.booking_tips: Book tickets well in advance, especially for popular performances or during holidays.

activities.name: Carnival (Carnevale) Events
activities.description: Experience local Carnival celebrations (dates vary, late winter/early spring) which may include parades, costumes, and special sweets.
activities.seasonal_notes: Celebrations leading up to Ash Wednesday. Intensity varies year to year.
activities.booking_tips: Check local announcements for specific dates and events related to Carnevale.

activities.name: Visit Museums on Cooler Days
activities.description: Take advantage of cooler winter weather to explore Palermo's indoor attractions like Palazzo dei Normanni, museums, and churches without the summer heat.
activities.seasonal_notes: Comfortable temperatures for extensive indoor sightseeing. Fewer crowds than peak season.
activities.booking_tips: Check opening hours, which might be reduced slightly in the off-season.

ranges.notes: Public holiday, many businesses closed, quiet start to the year.
Winter low season, fewer tourists, good time for museums.
Public holiday marking the end of Christmas festivities.
Shopping discounts begin. Cool weather, fewest crowds.
Possibility of local Carnevale events, especially in the lead-up to Lent. Generally cool weather, low tourism.
Weather starts to warm up, early spring flowers. Tourism still moderate.
Traditional day, look for special pastries ('sfince di San Giuseppe').
Increasingly pleasant weather. Potential for early Holy Week events if Easter is early.

ranges.event: Holy Week & Easter (Settimana Santa - variable dates)
ranges.notes: Major religious processions (especially Good Friday), peak spring atmosphere. Can be crowded.
National holiday, potential for local events, some closures.
Excellent spring weather, ideal for sightseeing, visiting gardens and Monreale.
Public holiday, many shops closed, locals may picnic or head to Mondello.

ranges.event: Start of Beach Season / Potential World Festival on the Beach
ranges.notes: Beautiful weather, perfect for exploring everything. Mondello gets busier. Check dates for World Festival on the Beach.
Start of summer, long sunny days, warm sea temperatures.
National holiday, potential parades or ceremonies, some closures.
Excellent summer weather, ideal for Mondello beach, boat trips, outdoor dining. Tourism high.
Hot summer weather, peak beach season, start of Sicilian Jazz Festival (check dates).
Palermo's biggest festival! Huge procession (14th), fireworks, street food. Very crowded but unforgettable.
Peak heat and peak tourism. Focus on beach, evening activities, indoor sights during midday. Sicilian Jazz Festival continues.
Hottest month, very high humidity, peak holiday time for Italians. Many locals leave the city. Some smaller shops/restaurants might close.
Major national holiday, widespread closures. Locals head to the beach (Mondello extremely crowded).
Continued heat, high tourism, focus on coastal activities and evening strolls.
Excellent weather, still warm enough for beach, sea is warm, crowds start to lessen slightly.

ranges.event: Potential start of 'Le Vie dei Tesori' (check dates)
ranges.notes: Ideal month for sightseeing. Check for start of cultural festival opening hidden sites.

ranges.event: 'Le Vie dei Tesori' cultural festival (typically weekends)
ranges.notes: Pleasant weather, good for exploring. Main month for 'Le Vie dei Tesori', opening numerous sites. Tourism moderate.
Public holiday, some closures. Traditionally time for visiting cemeteries.
Not a public holiday but culturally important. Look for special 'Frutta Martorana' (marzipan sweets).
Cooler, potentially rainy weather. Low season, ideal for museums and indoor sights without crowds.
Cool weather, start of festive season decorations.
Public holiday, official start of Christmas season, markets often open.
Markets (e.g., Politeama area), lights, festive atmosphere. Look for 'Presepi' (nativity scenes).
Family time, many closures on 25th. Midnight Mass options.
Public holiday, closures continue, quiet day.
Festive period between Christmas and New Year.
Public concert/celebrations often in Piazza Politeama. Restaurants offer special dinners (book way ahead).

summer: World Festival on the Beach (early summer)

scoreDescription.1: Poor: Generally unfavorable conditions for typical tourism (not generally applicable to Palermo)
scoreDescription.2: Below Average: Less ideal conditions, potential for closures (August), heat (August), or consistent cool/wet weather
scoreDescription.3: Average: Standard conditions, typical weather, potential for heat/closures (summer) or cool/rain (winter), moderate tourism or holiday peaks
scoreDescription.4: Good: Favorable conditions, good weather, possibly some key events, manageable or festive crowds
scoreDescription.5: Excellent: Ideal conditions, significant positive events, pleasant weather, potentially moderate crowds
